title: 2.3: Mesh Shape Emitters
summary: Learn to emit particles from 3D mesh surfaces using MeshShapeBlock
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn how to use MeshShapeBlock to emit particles from the surface of 3D meshes. This is powerful for creating effects that follow the shape of objects, such as sparks from a sword, smoke from a character, or particles that appear to come from a specific object in your scene. You'll create a complete particle system from scratch that demonstrates mesh-based emission.
steps: Create a SystemBlock - this is the root of your particle system
Create a CreateParticleBlock to emit particles
Set an initial color and size using ParticleInputBlock
Add a MeshShapeBlock to emit particles from mesh surface
Note: In a real scenario, you would reference an actual mesh from your scene
Add an UpdatePositionBlock to handle particle movement
Get Position and ScaledDirection, add them together, and connect to UpdatePositionBlock
Add an UpdateColorBlock and connect InitialColor contextual value to it
Add an UpdateSizeBlock with a constant size value
Chain the blocks: CreateParticle → MeshShape → UpdatePosition → UpdateColor → UpdateSize → SystemBlock
Add a ParticleTextureSourceBlock to provide a texture
Observe how particles are emitted from the mesh surface

blocks.name: MeshShapeBlock
blocks.description: Emits particles from the surface of a 3D mesh. Particles spawn on the mesh surface, following its shape. This is useful for creating effects that are tied to specific objects in your scene.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter

properties.name: mesh
properties.description: Reference to the 3D mesh from which particles will be emitted. The mesh must exist in the scene.

codeCopy: MeshShapeBlock allows you to emit particles from the surface of any 3D mesh in your scene. This creates a strong visual connection between the particles and the object, making it perfect for effects like sparks from metal, smoke from engines, or magical auras around characters. The particles spawn on the mesh surface, following its geometry, which creates natural-looking effects that adapt to the object's shape.
objectives: Understand MeshShapeBlock and its use cases
Learn how to reference meshes from the scene
Create particle effects tied to 3D objects
Understand the difference between mesh emission and other shape emitters
Apply mesh-based emission to real-world scenarios

commonMistakes.explanation: MeshShapeBlock requires a valid mesh reference. If the mesh doesn't exist or isn't properly referenced, particles won't emit correctly.
commonMistakes.solution: Ensure the mesh exists in the scene before using MeshShapeBlock. Reference it correctly using the mesh's name or direct reference.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using mesh emission for effects that don't need object attachment
commonMistakes.explanation: Mesh emission is more complex than other shapes. If you don't need particles tied to a specific object, use simpler shapes like PointShapeBlock or SphereShapeBlock.
commonMistakes.solution: Use MeshShapeBlock only when you need particles to follow an object's shape. For general effects, use Point, Sphere, Cone, or Box shapes.

homework: Create particles that emit from a character model
Try emitting particles from different parts of a mesh
Combine mesh emission with other effects (color changes, size variations)
Experiment with animated meshes to see how particles follow movement
Create a particle trail effect using mesh emission
